title.narrative: Preservation of the 16th-Century Father Tembleque Aqueduct, Phase 2

description.narrative: To support the continuation of work begun under a previous Ambassadors Fund grant to preserve the Tembleque (Zempoala) aqueduct in central Mexico, the most important work of hydraulic engineering built in the 16th century in the Americas. Extending more than 43 kilometers and built by more than 400 indigenous laborers under the general supervision of a Franciscan friar, the aqueduct demonstrates sophisticated construction techniques of pre-Hispanic origin dating back thousands of years. This project involves the restoration of the monumental Tepeyahualco arcade and associated hydrological structures.

title.narrative: Conserving Wetland Biodiversity: Capacity Building and Mapping Mexican Wetlands for Compliance with the Ramsar Convention

description.narrative: Assistance to Mexico to meet their obligations under the Ramsar Convention by mapping wetlands, training local personnel, and making wetland mapping data publicly available. It is in the United States interest to assist countries in managing and conserving their wetlands as the drinking water and food resources they supply are shared across international borders, including our own. Wetland conservation aligns with foreign policy objectives to promote healthy and productive populations and drive sustainable economic growth.

description.narrative: An exemplar of 16th-century Franciscan monastic architecture, the former Convent of Saint Martin de Tours sustained significant damage during the September 2017 Central Mexico earthquake. title.narrative: Trafficking in Persons Along Mexico Eastern Migration Routes: The Role of Me1ican Transnational Criminal Organizations

description.narrative: The University of Texas at Brownsville will conduct a study to investigate the role of transnational organized crime in human trafficking along Mexicos eastern migration routes. The research will identify the role that Mexican transnational criminal organizations (TCO) play in labor and Sex trafficking; identify links between Mexican TCOs and migrant smuggling to improve identification of victims of trafficking; and measure levels of collaboration between Mexican-originated TCOs and transnational criminal gangs to improve government authorities interdiction of traffickers.

title.narrative: Representing Victims of Trafficking for Access to Comprehensive Justice

description.narrative: In partnership with the NEXUS Institute and Instituto Tecnolgico Autnomo de Mxico (ITAM), the University of Michigan Law Schools Human Trafficking Clinic is now establishing a model legal clinic in Mexico City focused on building the capacity for legal advocacy and direct representation of VoTs in criminal and civil proceedings. The curriculum developed for clinic students will advocate a victim centered approach and assist in replicating the clinic throughout Mexico. Project was launched in Mexico City because of security and safety concerns in Zacatecas.
